figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Publication type of articles in Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017. Citable articles include reviews, original articles, case reports, information on liver pathology, and liver images. Non-citable articles include editorials, letters, corrections, and Clinical and Molecular Hepatology material published elsewhere.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Number of articles from Korea and other countries in Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Distribution of author countries other than Korea in Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017. USA, United States of America.

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: Changes in total citations to Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.

figure_5.title: Figure 5.
figure_5.caption: Changes in the 2-year impact factor of Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2014 to 2017.

figure_6.title: Figure 6.
figure_6.caption: Changes in the immediacy index of Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.

figure_7.title: Figure 7.
figure_7.caption: Countries of authors citing Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017. USA, United States of America.

figure_8.title: Figure 8.
figure_8.caption: Titles of the top 11 journals that cited Clinical and Molecular Hepatology in articles published from 2012 to 2017.

Open in a new tabStatistical analysis: Data were presented by descriptive statistics.RESULTS
Citable and non-citable articles were presented in Fig. 1.

Non-citable articles include editorials, letters, corrections, and Clinical and Molecular Hepatology material published elsewhere.The countries of authors from 2012 to 2017 for both citable and non-citable articles are presented in Fig. 2.
Authors from 28 countries outside of Korea have published in the journal, and the United States (23) and China (7) were the countries with the most frequent publications (Fig. 3).

Open in a new tab
Number of articles from Korea and other countries in Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.Figure 3.
USA, United States of America.Total cites are presented in Fig. 4.

Open in a new tab
Changes in total citations to Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.The impact factor (2-year) is presented in Fig. 5.

Open in a new tab
Changes in the 2-year impact factor of Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2014 to 2017.The immediacy index from 2012 to 2017 is presented in Fig. 6.

Open in a new tab
Changes in the immediacy index of Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.The countries of citing authors are presented in Fig. 7.
The titles of the top 11 journals that cited the journal most frequently are displayed in Fig. 8.
The number of articles by authors from outside Korea increased from 2 (4.8%) in 2012 to 23 (35.4%) in 2017 (Fig. 2).
Fig. 3 showed the number of articles from 28 countries outside of Korea from 2012 to 2017.

The increase of total cites from 1 in 2012 to 611 in 2017 was the most dramatic change for the journal’s reputation (Fig. 4), although the number of citable articles from 2012 to 2017 was 282 (Fig. 1).
The immediacy index also increased from 0.027 to 0.524 in 2017 (Fig. 6).
As for the country of citing authors’ affiliation, Korea, China, and the United States were the leading countries (Fig. 7).
Fig. 8 presents the titles of the 11 journals that have most frequently cited this journal.

Open in a new tabStatistical analysis: Data were presented by descriptive statistics.RESULTS
Citable and non-citable articles were presented in Fig. 1.

Non-citable articles include editorials, letters, corrections, and Clinical and Molecular Hepatology material published elsewhere.The countries of authors from 2012 to 2017 for both citable and non-citable articles are presented in Fig. 2.
Authors from 28 countries outside of Korea have published in the journal, and the United States (23) and China (7) were the countries with the most frequent publications (Fig. 3).

Open in a new tab
Number of articles from Korea and other countries in Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.Figure 3.
USA, United States of America.Total cites are presented in Fig. 4.

Changes in total citations to Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.The impact factor (2-year) is presented in Fig. 5.

Open in a new tab
Changes in the 2-year impact factor of Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2014 to 2017.The immediacy index from 2012 to 2017 is presented in Fig. 6.

Open in a new tab
Changes in the immediacy index of Clinical and Molecular Hepatology from 2012 to 2017.The countries of citing authors are presented in Fig. 7.
The titles of the top 11 journals that cited the journal most frequently are displayed in Fig. 8.
The number of articles by authors from outside Korea increased from 2 (4.8%) in 2012 to 23 (35.4%) in 2017 (Fig. 2).
Fig. 3 showed the number of articles from 28 countries outside of Korea from 2012 to 2017.

The increase of total cites from 1 in 2012 to 611 in 2017 was the most dramatic change for the journal’s reputation (Fig. 4), although the number of citable articles from 2012 to 2017 was 282 (Fig. 1).
The immediacy index also increased from 0.027 to 0.524 in 2017 (Fig. 6).
As for the country of citing authors’ affiliation, Korea, China, and the United States were the leading countries (Fig. 7).
Fig. 8 presents the titles of the 11 journals that have most frequently cited this journal.
